ResponsesInList.Title: Looking to map courses to a competency framework
ResponsesInList.Text: I would like to download the course name and the "about this course" page to enable mapping existing courses to a digital health competency framework created by WHO and / or a framework created by other entities such as world bank.  Is there a way to create a listing of specified courses and the description so that we can map them (100 - 200+ courses) to the appropriate frameworks?

ResponsesInList.Title: Looking to map courses to a competency framework
ResponsesInList.Text: You could create that list using SQL or Custom Reports (this took less that one minute on my site). I don't know how this will help you map them to the appropriate Competency frameworks? The frameworks are ancient, unforgiving structures.

ResponsesInList.Title: Allow Students to Add Competencies
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi everyone! I'm supporting a school that already uses CBL in their transition to Moodle from fully offline. Besides academic competencies, students are expected to self-evaluate and then work on a couple of soft skills per semester, in alignment with the school's graduate profile. I have enabled the capabilities competency:planviewowndraft and competency:planmanageowndraft for the authenticated user role, which worked fine. However, it quickly became overwhelming since students could see all the academic frameworks. I would like to find a way to restrict students from adding academic competencies to their individual plan. I have tried the following: Setting the soft skills framework to a category and creating a new role, at the category level, with the above capabilities. This didn't work (I suspect because learning plans exist at the user level) Doing the opposite, with the academic frameworks in a category, and setting competency:competencyview to prevent. The list looks clean but students are not allowed to view their rating, proficiency, etc. If there is no other option, I'll use tours to guide them, but I'd really appreciate any ideas you might have! Thank you, Inês

ResponsesInList.Title: Allow Students to Add Competencies
ResponsesInList.Text: I turned off all of those capabilities because we didn't want our student creating their own competencies, but I believe if you want to "hide" the competencies from the students just change the visible flag, to No. The admins can still see the competencies, but the students do not. You would need to test if other roles, Teachers/graders whatever you use in your organization who work with creating/editing competencies can still see the competencies. The top tier competency is the only one you would need to change (I know, easy to say I have 100+ top tiers....).

ResponsesInList.Title: Assigning Competency Levels based on Quiz marks
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, I have a competency for one module which ranks students based on their quiz results into four categories. Not Demonstrated (any result less than 40), Demonstrated (result between 40-70), Advanced (result between 71 and 90) and Excellent( anything above 90). I understood the steps of adding the competency to the module but was not successful in automatically generating the competency when a student completed the quiz. My question is: Is it possible to automatically generate the category of the competency when a student completes the quiz? If yes, will the system update the competency when the user reattempts the quiz and gets a better mark? Any help on the steps is highly appreciated. Thanks,

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Assigning Competency Levels based on Quiz marks
ResponsesInList.Text: Our competencies are not that sophisticated, an administrator or instructor would need to manually rate the competencies based on the scoring of the quiz. The Competency would also need the corresponding scale values set up for; Not Demonstrated, Demonstrated, Advanced and Excellent. You would also need to select at least one value as the default value. Kind Regards

ResponsesInList.Title: upon activity/curse completion
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, please could someone explain to me what each option containing "upon activity/curse completion" means (Do nothing/Attach evidence/Submit for review/Complete competency)? Thank you very much. Best regards. Veronica.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: upon activity/curse completion
ResponsesInList.Text: Do nothing - the competency will not be awarded to the student. Attach evidence - the student or instructor must upload a file before the competency is awarded the student. Such as Certificate of completion for an external course. Submit for review - the instructor will manually award the competency if the student's work supports achievement. Complete Competency - the competency is automatically award to the student if the complete conditions for the activity are met. Such as the student has a passing grade for that activity.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: upon activity/curse completion
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Shirley, thank you very much for your point by point explanation. Best regards. Verónica.

ResponsesInList.Title: 'block/lp:view' and setup instructions for Learning plan supervisor (system)
ResponsesInList.Text: Learning plan supervisor (system) setup instructions  on page >>> https://docs.moodle.org/400/en/Learning_plan_supervisor states to add block/lp:view to allow... * 5. Scroll down and set the capabilities moodle/site:configview, moodle/competency:templatemanage, moodle/competency:templateview and block/lp:view all to Allow. However, I do not have such a capability in my 4.06 moodle.  Upon further research, I found that, apparently, block/lp:view was removed in 2018 for Moodle3.53/3.6, and "fixed" in version 3.7 >>> https://tracker.moodle.org/browse/MDL-64124 Question , is this my ID10T error, or is this capability deprecated?  If deprecated, what should be the correct instructions for creating a Learning plan supervisor (system)? Thanks in advance... Best regards, Shemp *Learning plan supervisor (system) From Site administration, access the Define Roles screen and click the button to Add a new role. Click the Continue button. Give your role the name Learning plan supervisor (system) Tick 'System' as the context type where the role may be assigned. * Scroll down and set the capabilities moodle/site:configview, moodle/competency:templatemanage, moodle/competency:templateview and block/lp:view all to Allow. Save the new role.

Our idea is to have separate learning plans (LP)  for different leagues: referee - elite level referee - adults referee - juniors On the next level, we plan to have competencies (C) for different aspects of being a referee: understanding of handball - elite level leadership - elite level organisation and rules - elite level understanding of handball - adults leadership - adults organisation and rules - adults ... and so on ... And on the bottom level, we would like to have multiple courses, e.g. - understanding of handball - elite level group tactics - elite level offense - elite level defense - elite level ... and so on ... Our idea is that after completing the 3 courses (group tactics, offense, defense), the referee is awarded the competency of "understanding handball - elite level". Or do we need to add (child) competencies for each course and parent competencies for our planned competencies (understanding of handball, leadership, etc.)? ResponsesInList.Title: Re: award competency only after competion of multiple courses
ResponsesInList.Text: If you use the restrict access condition on your courses, so that the students must complete all courses in sequence, the competencies can be awarded on the last completed courses. Or they can be award in phases, Courses 1-3 award competencies A and B, Courses 4-6 award competencies C and D, and the last courses 7-9 award the final competencies E and F. Kind Regards

ResponsesInList.Title: Competencies and/ or Learning Plan?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, am just starting to use the Competency and Learning Plan and would need advice on best practices The main gist is that we want to have something like a report card at the end of the semester for the student, with a few competencies with a scale of "good", "proficient" for each competency etc 1. Is it OK to use the competency framework without using a learning plan? For example, I can add competencies to a course. Then link those competencies in a quiz, or graded assignment, is this a common approach? From student's perspective, when they go to the "Competencies" section, then they should see what competencies they are proficient in. I have not fully tested this out, but it seems to be possible. 2. Or should I be creating individual learning plans for each student to be graded for each competency I understand we can use cohort sync to assign learning plans for the entire cohort. However, it seems that that grading has to be requested from the student. Is there a way that teachers can review the competency at a certain time and manually input the grading scale for the students without getting students to request? 3. Is it possible to manually grade students for competencies? Understand that a better way is to use assignments or activities to track completion status. However, we are just starting to use Moodle, so many of our assignments, quizzes etc are not in the moodle system yet (could be paper form, or in other electronic form), so it will take some time to import all assignments into Moodle. Before we get to the state where everything is handled in moodle, is there a way to manually and easily assign the competency grade to the students? Thanks, David

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Competencies and/ or Learning Plan?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello David, 1. Competencies must have a relationship to a student's Learning Plan in order to display the student's competencies. The object being viewed is the Student's Learning Plan. 2. Normally, you create a Learning Plan Template and then add in all of the competencies for that learning plan. Each student may have a unique learning plan template or you could create learning plan templates that are common goals that all students in that area of study must achieve. 2a. Cohort Sync to learning plans will automatically link student's that are members of a cohort to a specific learning plan. Cohorts are mainly used to automate course enrollments. 2b. When a competency is related to a course activity the administrator can choose to either automatically award the competency to the student or have the activity manually rated by a teacher. The student will not be awarded the competency until the teacher rates it. I would only recommend manual rating for Essay or complex assignments. 3. Competencies are not grades. Competencies are an alternate method of tracking achievement. Please note the core Moodle structure does not have standard reports on Learning plans and student competencies. The UI for working with competencies and learning plans frameworks are very unforgiving. There are many past post in the forum that you could poke around and look at to provide you with a sense of the challenges if you decide to use competencies and learning plans.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Competencies and/ or Learning Plan?
ResponsesInList.Text: To address number 1) "Is it OK to use the competency framework without using a learning plan?" The answer is yes, if what you are primarily interested in is course alignment with standards for use in reporting, course design, accreditation, etc. Course competency frameworks are a very valuable source of information for helping with course design and standards alignment all in itself. For some institutions, this is all that what they currently need and may not yet be focused on or desirous of implementing the Learning Plans: they are focused on the course design phase. Also, I have seen a definite benefit in cases where an organization may not have experience with competency based learning models: they can use the frameworks to understand how those work. It is very valuable as the first step if you are not used to working in a competency based model. You can always progress later to add Learning Plans: but if you don't have the right set up for your frameworks to start with, and sufficiently well designed courses that align to the standards, it will probably be a less effective (and more confusing) if you rush into it.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Competencies and/ or Learning Plan?
ResponsesInList.Text: [EDIT] I figured out how to change the proficiency here, just to share, hopefully, it helps somebody else figuring out this issue down the road In the Course > Edit Settings > More > Reports > Competency Breakdown There is a screen where all the competencies are listed, and you can Rate each student's competency based on the pre-defined scale. ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Adding new learner to existing Learning Plan cohort

ResponsesInList.Title: Competencies: Less work for teachers?
ResponsesInList.Text: As far as my understanding goes: At the moment you can use competencies in Moodle as a teacher by doing a lot by hand. But I would like most of this work to be automated. So here is what I am looking for. According to local requirements, we have to rate competencies at four levels - which is not a problem to set up. However, in our courses we use a lot of automatically graded activities (or even assignments). But at the moment I don't see any way how I can automatically assign a student a high level of competency who has done very well in one of these activities, and a low level of competency to a student who has done less well. Doing that by hand is not only tedious (you don't see the points of an assignment or quiz in the competency overview, but also prone to error. And I don't really see the point of copying/replicating digitally available information by hand within the same system. The second problem I have: Some acitivities (rich in pedagogical content) are linked to several competencies, but as far as I see I can't award one of several competencies automatically whereas another one is just used as reverance. All these problems are in stark contrast to the fine grained possibilities when restricting activities depending on prior achievements Moodle already provides. That's why I want to ask whether there ary any plans to make the whole compentency framework more flexible? That would certainly save teachers a lot of time and frustration with teadious paper work. In case my conception of the possibilities and limitations of competencies are wrong, I'm more than happy to stand corrected.

ResponsesInList.Title: Competencies vs Activity Completion

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Competencies vs Activity Completion
ResponsesInList.Text: 'Hi all! I apologize if this is a stupid question.' It's an excellent question, but I am not the right person to answer it. However In my view Activity completion is much easier to understand and use than Competencies, but they are not really interchangeable things.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Competencies vs Activity Completion
ResponsesInList.Text: Competencies and learning plans are a whole separate system of tracking a students achievements. There is a lot of manually setup and upkeep and no delivered reports within Moodle. It is a necessary evil, for what I need to track - if it was not a requirement - I would just use the activity completion and Grades reports to evaluate if the training objectives were met. Within this forum - you can find some good data to support not going down that path. Kind Regards

ResponsesInList.Title: Activities-competencies relationship
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, where can I find the relationship between competencies and activities in the database ? role: Picture of Luis de la Torre

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Activities-competencies relationship
ResponsesInList.Text: Luis, You will find this in the table mdl_competency_modulecomp. The column cmid holds the id of the activity module in the mdl_course modules table, while the column comptencyid hold the particular competency id linking to the main mdl_competency table. That is how they are connected. Randy

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Competency Bird-Eye view for HR
ResponsesInList.Text: Learning plan 10,000 ft view 1. Competencies are created in the competency framework 2. Learning plan template are created with the desired competencies. 3. Student are assigned a learning plan which becomes their learning plan 4. Course are created that award the competency at a course activity. These are designed to be viewed by the student/Employee - it may be possible to allow manager/instructors to see this view but this takes changes to roles/permissions. Moodle core has no manager, instructor view - I use the plugin I mentioned above to achieve this. Courses - a. Courses contain content and/or activities that students (employees) must complete. You can set passing conditions such as a grade. b.Moodle has standardized core reports for course activity completion and course completion. c. All students who are enrolled in the course - current status and date they achieved the completion status. d. Students who successfully complete a course can achieve the competency which can be rated (automatic or manually). You should research some of the posting in this forum to see the issues that have come up - You should research the available Moodle documentation for competencies, learning plans, scales Maybe start here - https://docs.moodle.org/310/en/Competencies

ResponsesInList.Title: Request: Override main taxonomy at item level
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello to you all, Just to report the difficulties met when using the competency tools with french official competency frameworks (happy if someone has a solution) Different depths The official program board publishes the list of competencies but organized at different levels of the taxonomy: Domain Competencies Domain Domain Competencies Domain Domain Domain Competencies It means that when creating it in moodle, I need to create "fake" empty levels, to stay tuned with the taxonomy: Domain - Domain - Domain - Competency Domain Detail Detail Competencies Domain Domain Detail Competencies Domain Domain Domain Competencies This solution is really artificial. Different types at same level Moreover, the official program are organized with Competencies AND Associated Knowledge at the same level. Domain Domain Domain Competencies Knowledges PROPOSITION I would propose, as an evolution of the mdl_competency table, to have a column taxonomy_override to add the type of the item: domain, knowledge, concept, value... Exemple of a french program for audit and accounting: https://cache.media.enseignementsup-recherche.gouv.fr/file/25/01/5/ensup135_annexe1_1142015.pdf You can vote for the request in tracker https://tracker.moodle.org/browse/MDL-70652 Cheers François

ResponsesInList.Title: Best strategy for competency/learning plan setup
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi all, Very new to Moodle, but not new to LMS. When we get a new employee, I want to assign them something like a learning plan so they are batch enrolled in all the courses in the learning plan. First of all, is this how learning plans work? Creating learning plans requires creating competencies first, but I not sure how to organize the competencies. Here is the idea, tell me how I should configure this in Moodle. I really appreciate your help! For example, I have dinner chefs and bakers. Both jobs require Food Safety training. Only Chefs need Chicken Training. Only bakers need Frosting Training.  Chefs require Basic Oven training. Bakers require Advanced Oven training. Competency Framework: Oven Competencies: Basic Oven, Advanced Oven Competency Framework: Food Safety Competencies: Clean surfaces, Safe Temperature Competency Framework: Chicken Competencies: Deboning, Marinating Competency Framework: Frosting Competencies: Mixing, Spreading Learning Plan: Chef Competencies: all in frameworks Food Safety, Chicken, Advanced Oven Chef is assigned the Chef Learning plan, which enrolls her in all courses marked with the competencies Food Safety, Chicken, and Basic Oven. Learning Plan: Baker Competencies: all in frameworks Food Safety, Frosting, Advanced Oven Baker is assigned the Baker learning plan, which enrolls her in all courses marked with competencies Food Safety, Frosting, and Advanced Oven. Am I on the right track?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Best strategy for competency/learning plan setup
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Tennille, Competency Based Training as you explained needs to be made more task related and specific. Competency :-Basic Oven is insufficient as it would not allow the proper assessment. A simple approach can be to divide the task into three i.e. the pre activities , the activity and the post activity. What are the skills required for the task that relates  to the oven? Identify these in order. An oven is useful for baking or broiling:- Possible Pre-task:- Appropriate preparation of the oven:- 1. check the oven shelves (this determines quality) 2. presetting of the temperature gauge. 3. appropriate setting of the temperature gauge. (The difference between 2 and 3 is that it can be set but it was too high or too low.) Task:- 4. Proper placing of the chicken in the oven (for proper circulation of heat) 5. Sufficient baking time 6. Checking of product during baking. Post task:- 7 Turning oven off 8. Placing product in an appropriate place Check online, help can be found there. "Type competencies training  for bakers". I hope that you would be able to set up your plan. Best of luck Jemima

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Best strategy for competency/learning plan setup
ResponsesInList.Text: Competency Frameworks do not have to mirror your Learning Plans Template (Framework). Competencies from any framework can be added to a Learning Plan Template. You could have one large framework or hundreds. Note: once you setup a framework you cannot move the competency to another framework. Consider how your administrators will use these objects before you setup your framework(s). If you have one large framework, you can relocate a competency within the single framework. IMHO - I would create Food Safety as the top, Parent. I would create under Food, Chicken, Frosting, Chef, Baker. Under Chicken - deboning, Marinating. Before you can build your competencies frameworks, you have to consider scales. Scales cannot be changes once a student (employee) has been awarded the competency. We are using the Monitoring of Learning Plans plugin, which is more visual than the core design. Consider how you will use the competencies and learning plans. For Food Safety each employee will probably have to requalify annually or bi-annually. The competency objects have no end date, they never expire. Learning plans assigned to employees have no end-dates, they never expire. Deleting them removes the training history that you will need to retain for FDA. Kind Regards

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Best strategy for competency/learning plan setup
ResponsesInList.Text: Thank you for the informative answer. I wish we could use plugins, but we are using Moodle Cloud so we don't appear to have permissions to install them. I apologize that my example diluted the original question, which was: Is there a way to assign a student to [Moodle feature] which batch enrolls them in multiple relevant preselected courses?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Best strategy for competency/learning plan setup
ResponsesInList.Text: You might try cohorts, I use them. However, I manual build them vs the upload functionality as the instructions to do them is not completely intuitive. You may want to search the Enrollments forum, there have been some recent posting about cohort uploads. Kind Regards

ResponsesInList.Title: Locked competencies
ResponsesInList.Text: Is it possible to have students align with specific competencies and not others. i.e. higher ability students only accessing higher ability competencies within a course and unable to move on unless these are completed. Or a higher ability student only able to access higher ability content within a course based on the competency associated with it?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Locked competencies
ResponsesInList.Text: I do not believe that is possible. Course restriction rules are based on activities or grades. Competencies are awarded after the successful completion of an activity or passing grade. We currently do not have any restrictions if a competency is not achieved. IMHO I would create two separate courses and enroll the students to the appropriate course. I would also consider the lower level course a perquisite to the higher level course. Kind regards

ResponsesInList.Title: Migrating Competency Frameworks
ResponsesInList.Text: Apologies if this was already asked previously. I wasn't able to find anything related to this. If I set up an updated competency framework and migrated the competencies in the courses to the new framework, what will happen to the learning plans, assuming that there are already students with progress? I'm thinking that we need to set up new learning plans and transfer the students to this new one. However, will the migration also migrate their completion of the competencies? ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Migrating Competency Frameworks
ResponsesInList.Text: Why are you considering updating the competency framework? The students do not see the structure, the framework is only there for administrators of the structure. We have to live with what we created. Learning plans are within their own framework and it does not matter with the competencies are. The competencies linked to courses do not "care" where the competency is.

ResponsesInList.Title: Competencies - Parent
ResponsesInList.Text: Moodle 3.8 How do I create a parent in the Competencies framework? I have created to Competency framework and would like to organise competencies under a parent. Can't find where to do it.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Competencies - Parent
ResponsesInList.Text: Moving to Competencies forum...

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Competencies - Parent
ResponsesInList.Text: in the Competency framework, select the Add new competency framework, Add a competency, that is the parent. Select the parent and then Add Competency, those are the children. Competencies cannot be moved, so consider how you will work with these objects before you setup a large framework. I recommended looking at your scales before you start adding competencies. Each competency requires a scale with a proficiency (default) value. I also recommend that you only use Scales with values that do not include, Not Rated or Not Yet Competent, Scales cannot be changes once the competency is awarded to a student. Consider, how the different views look and what the student/instructors will see before you create your scale values.

ResponsesInList.Title: Using a quiz, not competent showing blue in progress bar, not red
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi there, as per the description, when a student is marked not competent, using a quiz, the progress bar stays blue, and doesn't change to red to indicate to the student they need to resubmit. Is it just the way the quiz is, or have I missed something in the setup?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Using a quiz, not competent showing blue in progress bar, not red
ResponsesInList.Text: This doesn't sound like a competency or learning plan question. 1. Does the quiz have a "passing" criteria? 2. Does passing the quiz award a competency to a student? 3. If it is only one student, did you look to see if they "passed" the quiz?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Using a quiz, not competent showing blue in progress bar, not red
ResponsesInList.Text: Hey Shirley Yes on Q1 and 2, and all students. Everything works fine, showing competent, etc. Was just wondering about the completion progress bar not showing red if not competent. If they are in fact marked competent (or passed), it shows green, like it should.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Using a quiz, not competent showing blue in progress bar, not red
ResponsesInList.Text: Competencies that are auto-awarded by activity completion work best with Scales = Competent, Completed, Proficient. One single value. Students who did not complete the activity are displayed as NOT RATED. My learning experience is to only create Scales with the single value - unfortunately this cannot be corrected. Scales cannot be changed after they are awarded, even if the one value is never awarded to a Student. Scales are very unforgiving. Competency that are manually rated by the Instructor can have multiple values for the Scale = Expert, Accomplished, Good, Fair, Needs Additional Effort. If I misunderstood your issue, please send a screen capture of the completion progress bar. Kind Regards

ResponsesInList.Title: Competencies Linked to Multiple Courses
ResponsesInList.Text: I am new to Moodle and am having trouble grasping competencies and learning plans in terms of making sure that students pass the required courses in order to achieve a competency. I have a competency framework called 'Account Management' and within that framework, I have a competency called 'Quoting'.   I want to assign this competency to two courses, however require that both courses be completed in order to be competent in Quoting.  Is this possible?   Or, would they become competent if they passed only one of the courses? Thank you in advance!!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Competencies Linked to Multiple Courses
ResponsesInList.Text: As soon as the activity is completed the competency is awarded. The "workaround" to your use case, would be to have a single course, with two activities and the students needs to complete/pass both activity to be awarded to competency. Courses are shells that may contain multiple activities before a student earn competency.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Competencies Linked to Multiple Courses

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Competencies Linked to Multiple Courses
ResponsesInList.Text: The parent-child relationships in the competency frameworks did not work as I expected and I abandoned those. Working with large competency structures (I have courses that award 18-20 competencies). in learning plans are cumbersome. Good Luck!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Competencies Linked to Multiple Courses
ResponsesInList.Text: Aaron, An alternative that may help is the Subcourse plugin: https://moodle.org/plugins/mod_subcourse . It's an activity that pulls in the final grade of another course into the course it is in. Since it is an activity it can have its own competency and do what Shirley suggested. Randy

ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, how to connect the quiz questions to competencies in Moodle

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: how to connect quiz questions to competencies
ResponsesInList.Text: You cannot link quiz questions to a competency. You can link a quiz activity - with a "rule" when the competency will be awarded. If you have a set of questions that would award competency #1 and another set of questions that would award competency #2 - your options are two quizzes each quiz award the specific competency. Or if the students completes the quiz that is not randomized that has both sets of questions - and achieves the passing conditions is awarded the competencies. Kind Regards.

ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Have set up a framework, and within a course assignment linked to two competencies - no problem. I have set upon activity completion to 'complete the competency'; I have set the Activity Completion to ' Show activity as complete when ... student receives a grade'. When the student is graded only the first of the competencies is shown to be a 'pass' in the Course Competencies page. Both show the link to the assignment OK. In the learning plan, it identifies that first competency as being met but not the second. I have tried linking the two competencies in the framework but that makes no difference. Please could you advise what I may be doing that is wrong? I am in Moodle 3.5.6+ Cheers Barbara

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Competency - assignment linking to 2 competencies
ResponsesInList.Text: Did you set up the two competencies are a parent-child relationship in the competency framework? If so, remove that relationship and simply add the second (former child) relationship to the course competency and then to the activity. If you did not use the parent-child relationship then screen captures would help.

Does one take precedence over the other; I have not noticed that if one is set up then the other follows suit. At the moment I am setting both but does seem duplication of effort. Sorry if something obvious I am missing here! Mank Barbara

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Competency - assignment linking to 2 competencies
ResponsesInList.Text: The options for awarding a competency Do Nothing (the instructor will manually rate this and award the competency) this is needed is you have various skill levels. Such as Expert, Advanced, Skills, Basic Understand, Improvement is needed. Attach Evidence, the instructor will manually rate this and award the competency after they review the attached evidence. If you are using the Assignment Course Activity this may be redundant...... Complete the Competency automatically awards the competency based on the related - course activity - completion rules.

ResponsesInList.Title: Linking competencies among courses

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Linking competencies among courses
ResponsesInList.Text: That functionality does not exist in Moodle core. The current UI does not allow competencies to move between frameworks. You can have multiple courses linked to the same competency, but you cannot link one competency to another unless it has the parent-child relationship within the same framework. IMHO the parent-child did not provide the functionality I  expected in my testing, The competency and Learning Plan template frameworks section of the UI needs to be rebuilt using the course catalog model.

ResponsesInList.Title: Thinking out loud:  A competency based Moodle site
ResponsesInList.Text: As a long time Moodler I started a few weeks ago thinking about use cases for competencies and learning plans in corporate or adult training program scenarios.  I would like to share and discuss my findings and ideas. Can we set up a Moodle site that is fully /mainly based on competency based learning/courses and how would it look like.? I'm not completely happy with my results, but it will be possible that I've overseen some options. But lets start at the beginning. We can create site wide or category related competency frameworks. A competency framework bundles several competencies and brings them into a hierachical order. Competency rules allows to defines rules that a user gets a top level competency if one or many other comptencies are met. Acitivity or course completion can be connected with one or many competencies. Its possible to connect the same competence in different courses. A participant can be enrolled into a learning plan. The user sees the learning plans and progress in the dashboard . When a learning plan is created  competencies are connected to the learning plan. Participants are enrolled to the learning plan via cohorts. Is it also possible for single learners? Its possible to define different levels of competencies. I.e. basic, standard, expert. How can we use it in a typical learning environment? For each learning topic and class level a competency framework is cretaed. They are connected to typical learning plans. At school it could be Class 8 English as a second language competency framework. Each teacher has an own classroom for each class in the term. He creates learning activties and connects them with competencies. Each students is connected with a learning plan (i.e. ESL class 8) The student can see the progress in dashboard. This model will work. But there are several issues I'm not happy with.: There are competencies that are not related to one topic only. (i.e. Presentation competency is an issue in German schools in class 8/9 in most topics for this class level). If each teacher adds activities for this competency students have to do  the same/similar very often and teacher don't see the progress/successs from other topics. As long as we have class and topic related courses teachers are isolated and everyone creates individual ressources, avctivities and didactical concepts. Cooperation and collaboration of teachers at schools are not part of their mindest (mostly here in Germany). So ist a lot of effort to create courses. This stops teacher to use a LMS intensive. Let me try to discuss an alternative model. Competency frameworks and learning plans are edited on site/category level. Courses are created for competencies not for classes. Instead of typical class and topic courses we create competency related courses. Its possible that for each competency several courses are available and the students enrolls themself. There are furthermore class/topic related courses. But the intention is different than typical. They are used for communication, some collaborative activities and final exam preparation. The student sees an overview about progress in the dashboard. This model tries  to push teachers to work collaborative and to use didactical scenarios from other teachers teaching the same topic. In some cases this could be  a little bit to radical/revolutionary. If this is your reality you can use the competency based courses as template and import them  into class related courses. I didn't check whether course related competency connections are included in backups.) What is missing? What I could not realize.... How can a teacher see the individual progress for a student? How can a teacher grade, comment the students activities? How can we limit the teachers access to his own students in the competency based courses? How can we implement didactical scenarios that needs group work? I also tried to understand how we can use taxonomies. After discussion with Mary we came to the result taxonomies are only descriptions. They are not related to any function.  Is this correct? Who can see the taxonomies? What do you think? Ralf This post was originally made in German community for didactical scenarios. https://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=380558

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Thinking out loud:  A competency based Moodle site
ResponsesInList.Text: Ralf, Thank you for a well written use case. Competencies, Learning Plan (student level) and the Learning Plan Templates need additional UI functionality to make them truly usable. The current UI displays, were not intended for hundreds of competencies and learning plans that a corporation/or adult training programs require. Cannot move structures - Learning plans, competency frameworks, learning plan templates. Cannot link parent competency to a learning plan, and have all children related to the learning plan. Cannot Search the learning plan templates The current UI does not include  the functionality for students that require annual retraining to "retain" their current competency level or to improve on their current competency level. Functionality to set a competency framework, learning plan template or learning plan to "inactive" to retain the history of the objects and relationships. Deleting removes the history. Completion of a students learning plans to remove make it inactive is inappropriate, but it is the only option. Need the ability to "grandfather" a student for a competency and enter the dates of achievement. Students in the corporate world complete training outside of the LMS - and administrators often are provided evidence long after the course was completed. The taxonomies should be been at a system configuration level vs. the individual competency framework. These are just the thoughts off the top of my head.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Thinking out loud:  A competency based Moodle site
ResponsesInList.Text:
Thankyou Shirley for your post - some responses to points you raised are below: 
```text
Cannot link parent competency to a learning plan, and have all children related to the learning plan.
```
 When selecting a competencies, the competencies are displayed in an accessible tree which has some keyboard shortcuts that might help. '*' key expands all nodes in the tree 'shift' click will select all nodes in between two points in the tree. So you can quickly select all nodes in any branch of the tree. 
```text
"The taxonomies should be been at a system configuration level vs. the individual competency framework."
```
 The framework defines what the taxonomy should be and changing the taxonomy for one framework should not affect other ones. 
```text
Functionality to set a competency framework, learning plan template or learning plan to "inactive" to retain the history of the objects and relationships.
```
 This does exist already - when a new version of a framework is created, the old one can be set to not "visible" which retains and will show the history of objects and relationships, but will prevent the competencies in the "old framework" from being selectable
when adding competencies to a course / learning plans etc. There is then also the Migrate Frameworks tool to update all the competencies in courses from the old framework to the new one.

Sequencing them by the ID vs. manually moving them one-by-one, like the course category would be the desired functionality. Setting framework to not visible (hide), did not remove the learning plan from the student's view during my initial testing. Maybe there is a cron job that needs to run, or run more often? Or the functionality does work as expected. I am not concerned an admin picking the wrong competencies, I am concerned with the students' view of their learning plan(s). I need to reorganize an existing structure, because my business reorganized a department. I need to move a framework to a new category.

ResponsesInList.Title: adding competency framework default to course
ResponsesInList.Text: Once competency frame work is created, how it can be configured such that all the courses are automatically linked to competency while creating new course, also, the competency is default present for search while uploading the content of a course

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: adding competency framework default to course
ResponsesInList.Text: Linking multiple course to a competency can be done, but once a student "earns" the competency on any course, there will be no compelling reason to complete the other courses. Normally, course to competency are a one-to-one relationship. Or some courses with multiple activities , may award multiple competencies. There is no search for competencies for students. You need to add the competencies to your courses and then set which course activities will award which competencies. You also need to link competencies to learning plan templates, and add students to learning plans. There is a large amount of administrative set-up and no delivered reports.

ResponsesInList.Title: Tenuous link between learning plans and competencies in a course
ResponsesInList.Text: Essentially the only thing holding our Moodles back from implementing competencies is that I don't see a way to display to students which activities in a course contribute to completion of a learning plan that was assigned to them. In our use case, doing the whole course isn't always required, so students could pick and choose to be proficient in the competencies (and their corresponding activities) relating only to their learning plan. MDL-53346 would help resolve this somewhat bit I was wondering if anyone has a workaround that I may have missed? Short of getting the student to write down all the competencies required to complete a learning plan and then visiting the course competencies page to see which activities to do, the connection between a learning plan and a competency isn't sufficiently clear for students.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Tenuous link between learning plans and competencies in a course
ResponsesInList.Text: If a learning plan can be "completed" by various competencies, I would list all of the competencies in the Learning Plan Template description field. Example: this learning plan can be completed by achieving any of the following course awarded competencies. Math 101 Math and Practical Applications Math for ...... Math for .....

ResponsesInList.Title: Competency Framework optional fields description
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi all, My organization tends to uses Competency Based Learning. To prepare our import file,  i downloaded one of the of the frameworks from moodle repository and i understand most of the fields there  except the following optional fields: Rule type Rule outcome Rule config Cross-referenced competency Exported Please, Can anyone explain or provide me with resources that explain what these optional  fields mean? Thank you

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Competency Framework optional fields description
ResponsesInList.Text: Within a competency family you can create "rules" between two of the children. You cannot create a "rule" between children of separate families. Depending on how to built your competency framework, the rules may or may not be usable. If you have a single parent that will have all the same scales, you may want to see where you would want to link children. If the student is awarded competency A they will also achieve competency B. I have many parents that use different scales - so I cannot use rules.

ResponsesInList.Title: Competencies over time
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, this might be a stupid question, but I was just wondering what happens to Competencies attached to a course, when a student has completed the course and the course is reset? Do competencies follow a student over time... regards, Brad

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Competencies over time
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello, Students' learning plan are not affected by course reset, but attached evidences coming from this course will be erased, and therefore we will have broken links in the learning plans. Maybe someone can give more precisions, but I think this is what will happen. If we think about an institution life-cycle, former year course will be erased, or maybe two or three years ago courses, and eventually we will have data in the data base (who and when acquired a competence, who validated it...) but some of the evidences will go away. Best,

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Competencies over time
ResponsesInList.Text: If you need to retain the history of the student's competency, you should not use the course reset option. You could backup, restore a course as a "new" name and ID. Deselect the current enrollments and competencies to have a "fresh" course for new enrollments and if needed, a competency for the current year/skill. Best Regards, Shirley

ResponsesInList.Text: Competencies are created in the Competency Framework. Existing competencies are "related" to a course. Courses can automatically "award" a competency when course activities are completed or they can be manually added by an instructor later. ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Can students choose a competency to attach to an assignment?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello, Inside the courses, students are not able to select which activities can prove they are competent in a particular competence, but there is another way that can be useful for you: student learning profiles. If a student clicks on Profile > Learning plans, s/he will find, under the list of Learning plans, an option to add evidences (Links, Files). Once the evidence added s/he can link it to any of the competencies included in his/her learning plans. The problem here is that teachers will not see students' learning plans, as they are outside the courses. Extra permissions will need to be assigned to the person managing the assessment of these competencies. (Look https://docs.moodle.org/35/en/Learning_plan_supervisor , https://docs.moodle.org/35/en/Learning_plan_viewer and https://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=370384 Cheers, R

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Can students choose a competency to attach to an assignment?
ResponsesInList.Text: I have seen college level coursework, when the student's selected from the competency offerings for each course which competency they wanted to apply to their rubric. However, I cannot think of a systemic way of doing this in Moodle. You could include on the course summary page - a list of each of the competencies. Then add within the course a quiz activity with a single select one question. Each of competency is listed and the student "declares" which competency value is their goal upon course completion. When the course is successfully completed, the instructor can award the requested competency value. You would still need to build or the competency framework and relate them to the course. Consider how to build out your scales for the competencies before you implement. Such as; Submitted evidence for this competency, no submitted evidence, alternative evidence was submitted. Best Wishes, Shirley

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Competencies: Activity Grade based on "Complete the competency" and Completion Tracking
ResponsesInList.Text: Competencies should reflect the specific course objectives. Once a competency is earned, the student will not be required to complete any other course that awards the competency. Each course that you need a student to complete in their learning plan must have a unique competency-course relationship.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Competencies: Activity Grade based on "Complete the competency" and Completion Tracking
ResponsesInList.Text: Your Construction Management course sounds like an apprentice program which has many courses the employee is required to complete in order to achieve apprenticeship. I have in the past created the 50 unique course elements, with unique competencies for each of the required skills. The Construction Management can be a certificate that requires the 50 competencies. I would not create one course with 50 elements. I might even consider breaking down the 50 elements into sub-categories - to keep the learners engaged with the apprentice process. The each quarters question needs some additional clarification from you. Do you have new employees each quarter for the same 50 courses? If so, just use cohort sync for the next quarters enrollment to the same 50 courses.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Managing expiry date of accreditations/ competencies
ResponsesInList.Text: There are some ways to do something similar to what you describe. E.g. You can make learning plans expire on a specified date. You can create duplicate a competency framework annually and you can migrate courses from one version of a competency framework to the next (without having to manually update all the courses). These features can be put together to require someone to annually re-achieve a competency (which is a actually a new competency for every year). Expiring a competency after a time period or on a certain day has been mentioned but I don't think anyone has created a tracker issue for it (it seems like a good idea).

ResponsesInList.Title: Reopening learning plan?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello, When i reopen learning plan it gives an warning; "Reopen the learning plan 'XXXXXX'? If so, the status of the users' competencies that was recorded at the time the plan was previously completed will be deleted, and the plan will become active again." But is anything actually destroyed/lost besides Status that changes from "complete" to "active" ?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Reopening learning plan?
ResponsesInList.Text: When a learning plan is completed, the state of all the competencies in the plan is frozen at the point in time the plan was completed. So if student A has a plan which is completed in January - but they only achieved 1 / 5 competencies from their plan - the plan will always reflect 1 / 5. If in February, then go on to complete all 5 competencies (maybe in another course), the plan will still say 1 / 5. If the plan is re-opened - the "frozen state" of the plan is deleted - the plan will now say 5 / 5 completed and there will be no record of what their progress was in January.

ResponsesInList.Title: ACGME Competency Framework
ResponsesInList.Text: Please share your views and latest frameworks created for ACGME core competencies used in medical schools

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: ACGME Competency Framework
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Samal I think you talk  about Milestones. Milestones As the ACGME began to move toward continuous accreditation, specialty groups developed outcomes-based milestones as a framework for determining resident and fellow performance within the six ACGME Core Competencies. What are Milestones? Simply defined, a milestone is a significant point in development. For accreditation purposes, the Milestones are competency-based developmental outcomes (e.g., knowledge, skills, attitudes, and performance) that can be demonstrated progressively by residents and fellows from the beginning of their education through graduation to the unsupervised practice of their specialties. Who developed the Milestones ? Each specialty’s Milestone Working Group was co-convened by the ACGME and relevant American Board of Medical Specialties (ABMS) specialty board(s), and was composed of ABMS specialty board representatives, program director association members, specialty college members, ACGME Review Committee members, residents, fellows, and others.

ResponsesInList.Title: can student rate the competencies of the course??
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, can student rate the competencies of the course? if currently, students can't do that is it possible to do it by changing one of the capabilities or by any plugin I really appreciate any help you can provide.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: can student rate the competencies of the course??
ResponsesInList.Text: There is not a way to directly rate competencies that I know of, but you could set up a feedback or questionnaire to do that. Also, if you wanted to do it simpler than those two options, you could use the HotQuestion activity as a competency rating or suggestion box with vote capability on each entry. Full disclosure, I currently maintain the HotQuestion plugin. You could also try the Poll block.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: can student rate the competencies of the course??
ResponsesInList.Text: We (Dutch Moodle users at our Moot last week) happen to have discussed possibilities for this. If you mean rating competencies in the same way a teacher would do for a student, but more in a peer assessment kind of way, you could try one of the custom roles for this. A huge note of caution though: in peer assessment it's most useful to have at least 3 assessments per user, to have a nicely balanced score/rating. With the current set up of reviewing and rating competencies, this can not be done: 1 rating per competency. This probably has to do with the nature of CBL/CBE and the preferred 'competent/not yet competent' scale for this. In such a black-and-white situation, there is no place for multiple assessments/ratings for any given competency: you're either competent or you're not.

ResponsesInList.Title: Competence Frameworks - how far to drill down Vs courses...
ResponsesInList.Text: Greetings all, I am not sure where I should post this, so starting here, let me know if it should be elsewhere. MOODLE v3.2 - Competence Frameworks, I am creating a framework at site level (we have no defined standard internationally or nationally).  I have my 5 top level competencies, and I am breaking them down into smaller chunks against which activities will be judged. What I want to know, is at what level I should be defining, or breaking down the competencies into performance criteria at the framework level  and where I I stop and then have the remainder defined within a course.   This is hard to explain. For example, if I have a top level competence, say COMMUNICATE then that is one of the top level competence elements in the framework.   Then say I am testing communication in terms of written and oral.  So I have two subcompetencies COMMUNICATE - written and COMMUNICATE- oral.  Then the written communication requires that the people use the correct systems or technology, use appropriate language, and, say, cover the right material.  Should those three sub-sub-competencies be in the framework, or in the course? Is there any kind of standard that anyone knows of? Many thanks for any thoughts, or any advice on where else this kind of topic is discussed, I know it isn't really to do with moodle, moodle is just the tool, but I figured someone here might have hit this problem before me! Cheers Michelle

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Competence Frameworks - how far to drill down Vs courses...
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Michelle, This is more a CBE (Competency Based Education) question than a tool one, but I'll see if I can help you (as the topic has my particular interest). The key is to be as concrete as possible when elaborating the competencies in your framework, limiting each competency to one specific behaviour/skill/situation. For your example, this could mean: Communicate Oral Informal I can have a phone conversation I can ask questions about something personally relevant, such as directions to the nearest bus stop etc... Formal Written Informal I can write a post card from my vacation address I can IM with a friend I can write a status update for my social media Formal I can write a formal letter to apply for a job I can write a resumé to accompany my job application I can write an email to a potential employer to apply for a job And so on... one good source for this elaborate breakdown of competencies/skills/can-do statements is the Common European Framework of Reference for Languages, aka CEFR. If this is not a foreign language thing you're after, you might want to look into descriptors for soft skills, that are bound to be out there.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Competence Frameworks - how far to drill down Vs courses...
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Joost! Thanks for the reply,  I have done more research and thought and discussed this at work.  I am going to add one thing.  Thanks for your post, that helped to get me started! Basically I have decided to split the framework elements Vs course measurables using elements that are non-perishable (and hence in framework which stands the test of time) Vs perishable (measurable in course that might change in the future). i.e.  Oral - informal and Oral - Formal would be part of the framework, we can assume that these will be required forever (non-perishable).  However, the medium used for oral communication (phone/video.) is perishable, the phone may cease to exist, video may become hologram (?!) .  I'd argue that the ability to ask questions is non-perishable, where as using a particular system (phone/twitter/facebook etc) are perishable.  So I'd be putting the system based performance criterion in the course, and the non-perishable in the framework. Does this sound sensible to others? Joost, should I be adding this to CBE discussion? Not sure where that is.... Thanks! Michelle

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Competence Frameworks - how far to drill down Vs courses...
ResponsesInList.Text: It sounds sensible to me... focus on behaviors, skills (or whatever taxonomy you plan to use) and make them about as specific as is needed, without restricting a behavior to a tool that's presently being used for it. You're right in saying that communication skills don't necessarily depend on the tool used: even when humans used drums or smoke signals, they still needed to master the skill of asking questions, answering them and exchanging information in an efficient way. Same goes for computer skills: tool-related stuff can be managed in in-course tasks (being able to store a document made with MS Office Word on a laptop by using the short key Ctrl-S), whereas the skill 'I can create, edit and save a text document' would be handled in a competency framework.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Automatic Competency ID Number by default
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello François and thanks for the compliment. I don't know of an automatic way to have them filled in, but you could make a tracker new feature request and see if others are interested in this as well. https://tracker.moodle.org

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Automatic Competency ID Number by default
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, Mary, good Idea and thanks for the link... Although JIRA doesn't allow me to create a new issue (surely not mature enough yet ;) ) I have posted a comment on a closed ticket... Hope nobody will mind too much about it. Have a nice day. Regards François

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Automatic Competency ID Number by default
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi François, JIRA is a bit of a strict system. In order to be able to post an issue in the Tracker, you have to vote for a number of related issues, so you can prove you're a human being. This prevents the Tracker from being spammed by bots and other things. As for the competency ID numbering, I normally work with a spreadsheet program, set the framework ID to 1000 for instance, the main categories within the framework to 1001, 1002, 1003, etc, and then use the spreadsheet to auto +1 the value for every competency in there. Automating this in the interface may seem like a useful feature, but working with a framework of over 100 competencies, it's a bit of a task keeping track of all the layers and subcompetencies. You have to keep track of the parent competencies and their ID numbers in order to be able to correctly relate them. I found working with a spreadsheet > CSV a lot faster than the interface.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Automatic Competency ID Number by default
ResponsesInList.Text: Hmm, I think for categories, there are 2 'ID numbers': 1 autonumbered which is also the database ID number corresponding to the category, and 1 optional value that just displays in your category management section. If the developers used this to model the competency settings page, it makes sense that the competency ID number is an optional value, only to be used for reference. And for auto numbering, you'd have to allow for instances who want an alphanumerical ID number, instead of just a numerical value, like 'e1234c345b1' It might be an interesting addition to the interface and workings, and it could be part of improvements to the interface.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Enroll student into Learning Plan
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Baiju, First of all, there are 2 very different ways of working with competencies, as you already noted: - through student or cohort assigned learning plans - through competencies linked to a specific course and the activities in this course I am not aware of any ways of linking a learning plan to a student, other than creating a learning plan based on a template and then assigning it to a cohort or individual student. Since learning plans can contain competencies from multiple courses, I do not see any analogy with enrolling a student into a course.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Enroll student into Learning Plan
ResponsesInList.Text: In our case. They start with an "initiation course" which takes them to higher level courses. ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Enroll student into Learning Plan
ResponsesInList.Text: If there are competencies linked to the course (and/or it's activities), these will show up in the Competencies list available to students. Here, a student will see to what degree he is competent, and to which activities the competencies are linked. A teacher can access the competencies breakdown report to see how each student's doing within the course.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Required SQL for taxonomies

ResponsesInList.Title: Adding competency(s) to an activity or resource...

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Adding competency(s) to an activity or resource...
ResponsesInList.Text: I don't know if you can make competency a required field in any activity or resource. IMO that would lead to undesirable situations where your teachers/instructors will just pick a random competency to be done with it, or don't use any activities altogether. The way the competency frameworks are meant to be used, is through Learning Plans, that can be linked to cohorts or individual students in your LMS. At a course level, competencies might be useful to be linked to one activity, but not to others...

ResponsesInList.Title: Competency taxonomies
ResponsesInList.Text: I am using Moodle v3.2 and would like to edit the taxonomies available. The list of available levels is incomplete from my perspective and I would like to establish the following taxonomies under a competency: Skill: Capabilities aquired through practice. Knowledge : Understanding aquired through learning. Personal attributes : Inherent characteristics which are brought to the job. Behavior : The observable demonstration of some competency, skill, knowledge and personal attributes attributed to excellent performance. I also think that for some competencies 4 levels is inadequate and for others may be too much. I would like to suggest that the framework be more adjustable and editable. For example: Have a pull down so the user can indicate the number of taxonomy levels they require when creating a competency and also a way to edit the options available for the levels.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Competency taxonomies
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks for the feedback. The framework can actually have any number of levels. If you have less than 4 - the last taxonomy terms from the edit competency framework form will just not be used. If you create a framework and add more than 4 levels of competencies to it, then go back to the edit competency framework form - you will see you can choose taxonomy terms for the additional levels (no limit). If you have taxonomy terms that you want to use that are not in the list of predefined options - I recommend you edit the language strings for one of the existing terms that you don't want to use.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Competency taxonomies

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Competency taxonomies

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Learning plan report
ResponsesInList.Text: How do I run a report that shows me how students in my class, building and system are doing on a particular competency. For instance, a competency in Minnesota 4th grade Science is " 4.2.3.2.3, Demonstrate how an electric current can produce a magnetic force. For example: Construct an electromagnet to pick up paperclips." That competency (Minnesota calls it a benchmark) is one competency in the group of standards, named, 'Energy can be transformed within a system or transferred to other systems or the environment.' The group that that standard is in is called "Energy" which is a group in the larger group, Physical Science, which is in the larger group Mn 4th Grade Science Standards. I would like to use an off line submission of an Assignment activity that includes a rubric to determine whether or not the student(s) have achieved mastery of that competency. I would likely have a comprehension quiz and another simple assignment on which students would need to earn a certain grade and complete before they attempted the Construct an electromagnet project. As the Director of Elementary Science (theoretically) for a school district that includes 45 elementary schools that each have on average 3 classes of 4th graders, I want to run a report on that competency by class, by building and for the whole district. I would also like to be able to drill down and view the artifact submitted by each student, and the completed rubric with teacher comments, in fulfillment of this competency. There are twenty other 'benchmarks' in 4th Grade Science with hierarchical groupings at each of the above levels. I will also like to run reports on aggregations of those 'scores' by all of the above. How do I set-up reports like that? Here's a pdf of all of the Minnesota K12 Science Minnesota K-12 Academic Standards in Science (2009)

ResponsesInList.Title: competency and outcome
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi all, I'm a little bit confused about the new competency feature that is introduced with Moodle 3.1. Can someone please enlighten how it is different from outcomes? As it is stated in MoodleDocs for Outcomes : Outcomes are specific descriptions of what a student has demonstrated and understood at the completion of an activity or course. Each outcome is rated by some sort of scale. Other terms for outcomes are Competencies and Goals.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: competency and outcome
ResponsesInList.Text: Greetings Martin - I agree - I was just about to post this - so thank you.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: competency and outcome
ResponsesInList.Text: I also agree about outcomes and competencies being confusing! In Moodle, there is a site administration setting called 'Enable outcomes' and in 3.1, the description of this setting has been changed to 'If enabled, grade items may be graded using one or more scales tied to outcome statements.' Thus, outcomes in Moodle are to do with grading only. There is also a site administration setting in 3.1 called 'Enable competencies', the description of which is 'Competencies allow users to be assessed according to learning plans.' The documentation Competencies provides a fuller explanation, mentioning competency frameworks too. Thus, competencies in Moodle 3.1 are a lot more complex than outcomes!

We are now very integrated to the Moodle gradebook and in my opinion in the short time I spent in working through the competency framework - I would love to be able to attach it to the graded item and to evaluate the results through the gradebook. I know there is a work around but I would like to encourage the developers to add them to the gradebook for adding it to a graded item and the category. Thank you again, Nancy K.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: CBE import plugin
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Khaled, There is a plugin for importing CBE frameworks, but so far as I know it is not yet in the Moodle download s area. You can get it anyway from github at https://github.com/damyon/moodle-tool_lpimportcsv It needs to be installed in yourmoodle/admin/tool and once installation is completed, you will have an Import and Export link added under Competencies. Works nicely and will let you match your csv file columns to the one used by Moodle CBE frameworks, if they are not the same already.
